metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which sequence correctly lists Earth’s layers from the surface to the centre?

answers.content: Crust → Mantle → Outer Core → Inner Core
answers.explanation: The crust is the outermost layer, followed by the mantle, the liquid outer core, and finally the solid inner core.

answers.content: Mantle → Crust → Outer Core → Inner Core
Crust → Outer Core → Mantle → Inner Core
Mantle → Outer Core → Inner Core → Crust

questions.question: Why is the inner core solid even though it is approximately as hot as the surface of the Sun?

answers.content: Because it is made of rock, not metal
Because immense pressure prevents the iron–nickel alloy from melting
answers.explanation: Extreme pressure at Earth’s centre raises the melting point of the iron–nickel alloy so it remains solid despite high temperature.

answers.content: Because it is cooler than the outer core
Because gravity pulls the particles tightly together in the mantle

questions.question: Which layer of Earth is responsible for the slow convection currents that drive plate movement at the surface?

answers.content: Crust
Mantle
answers.explanation: The semi-solid mantle circulates slowly, moving tectonic plates that sit on the crust.

answers.content: Outer Core
Inner Core

questions.question: Select the property that best describes the outer core.

answers.content: Rigid, brittle and very thin
Semi-solid silicate rock that flows slowly
Liquid iron and nickel that generates Earth’s magnetic field
answers.explanation: The molten outer core is composed mainly of iron and nickel whose movement produces Earth’s magnetism.

answers.content: Cool, solid layer where life exists

questions.question: Scrat falls through the crust quickly in the film clip. What is the MAIN reason the crust takes the shortest time to pass through compared with deeper layers?

answers.content: The crust is the thinnest layer.
answers.explanation: Even though the crust is rigid, it is much thinner than the mantle and cores, so it takes the least time to traverse.

answers.content: The crust is the coldest layer.
The crust is made of liquid rock.
Gravity is weaker at the crust.

questions.question: Define the term mantle using Tier 3 scientific vocabulary.

answers.content: The mantle is a thick, semi-solid silicate layer beneath Earth’s crust in which convection currents transfer thermal energy.

questions.question: Explain in one or two sentences how adding heat energy affects the arrangement of particles when rock changes from the mantle to form magma.

answers.content: When heat energy is added, the particles in solid mantle rock gain kinetic energy, move farther apart and overcome some of the forces holding them in a rigid structure, causing the rock to melt and become liquid magma.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-section of Earth that shows the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. Use colour and annotations to describe thickness and temperature for each layer.

answers.content: Teacher-marked drawing activity

questions.question: What is the main cause of most earthquakes on Earth?

answers.content: The sudden release of energy when tectonic plates become unstuck along a fault line
answers.explanation: When pressure builds where two plates are locked together, it is suddenly released, causing the ground to shake.

answers.content: Waves created by strong ocean currents
The Moon’s gravitational pull on Earth’s crust
The expansion of Earth’s inner core

questions.question: In the Mars bar model, which part of the chocolate bar represents Earth’s rigid crust?

answers.content: The solid chocolate coating on the outside of the bar
answers.explanation: The hard outer layer of the Mars bar stands for Earth’s crust, which cracks and buckles when the ‘plates’ are pushed together.

questions.question: Why does Australia experience comparatively few large earthquakes?

answers.content: Australia lies in the centre of a tectonic plate, far from most plate boundaries
answers.explanation: Most strong earthquakes occur at plate boundaries; Australia is situated well inside the Indo-Australian Plate.

answers.content: Australia’s landmass is too heavy to move
Australia is surrounded by very deep oceans that absorb shock waves
Australia’s climate keeps the crust stable

questions.question:
Complete the sentence using the causal connective ‘so’ to show cause and effect:

“The earthquake struck the coastline, ___ the land rose up and changed the shape of the shore.”

answers.content: so
answers.explanation: ‘So’ links the cause (earthquake) with the effect (land rose up).

questions.question: When the epicentre of an earthquake is beneath the ocean it can generate a ______, which is:

answers.content: tsunami – a series of large, powerful ocean waves that can flood coastlines
answers.explanation: Sub-sea earthquakes displace huge volumes of water, creating destructive tsunami waves.

answers.content: whirlpool – a fast-spinning body of water that pulls objects downward
hurricane – a rotating storm system with high winds
tidal bore – a single wall of water that moves upriver with the tide

questions.question: What is the correct scientific term for molten rock found BELOW Earth’s surface?

answers.content: Lava
answers.explanation: Lava is molten rock AFTER it reaches the surface.

answers.content: Magma
answers.explanation: Molten rock beneath the crust is called magma.

answers.content: Ash
answers.explanation: Ash is fragmented material ejected into the air during eruptions.

answers.content: Sediment
answers.explanation: Sediment is weathered rock deposited elsewhere.

questions.question: During the classroom model eruption, which household substance REACTS with vinegar to create the ‘lava’ foam?

answers.content: Table salt
Baking soda
answers.explanation: Baking soda reacts with vinegar to release carbon-dioxide bubbles that simulate lava flow.

answers.content: Sugar
Cooking oil

questions.question: Which of the following is an IMMEDIATE change to the landscape caused by a volcanic eruption?

answers.content: Formation of new land such as islands or lava plains
answers.explanation: Cooling lava hardens into new rock, instantly adding land.

answers.content: Erosion of riverbanks over thousands of years
Movement of continents by plate drift
Glacial melting at the poles

questions.question: Most volcanoes form where tectonic plates:

answers.content: Slide past one another (transform boundaries)
Move apart or collide (divergent or convergent boundaries)
answers.explanation: Divergent and convergent boundaries allow magma to rise through weaknesses in Earth’s crust.

answers.content: Remain completely stationary
Fold to create mountain ranges without magma

questions.question: Give TWO ways volcanic eruptions can be CONSTRUCTIVE (beneficial) for people or ecosystems.

answers.content: Possible answers include: 1) Volcanic ash breaks down into very fertile soil that improves farming yields. 2) Cooling lava creates new land such as islands that plants and animals can colonise. 3) Geothermal energy near volcanoes can be harnessed for electricity or heating.

questions.question: Using a causal connective such as “because” or “therefore,” explain a KNOCK-ON effect of fertile volcanic soil on a nearby human community.

answers.content: Sample answer: "Because volcanic ash weathers into nutrient-rich soil, local farmers can grow larger crops, therefore the community enjoys an abundant food supply and increased income."

questions.question: Draw and label a simple cross-section of a volcano that includes: magma chamber, main vent, crater, and lava flow.

answers.content: Teacher-scored drawing should clearly show and label the four required parts. Full marks for correct placement and labels.

questions.question: Which ancient Roman city was famously preserved under ash after Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 AD?

answers.content: Athens
Pompeii
answers.explanation: Ash buried Pompeii, preserving buildings, artefacts and even food.

answers.content: Carthage
Sparta

questions.question: What is weathering?

answers.content: The breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces by natural forces.
answers.explanation: Weathering involves physical or biological forces that break rocks apart.

answers.content: The movement of broken rock from one place to another.
answers.explanation: This describes erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: Molten rock cooling and hardening.
answers.explanation: This describes igneous rock formation.

answers.content: Human mining of minerals.
answers.explanation: Mining is not a natural weathering process.

questions.question: Which combination lists ONLY agents of weathering studied in this lesson?

answers.content: Wind, moving water, plants
answers.explanation: These three agents were the focus of the lesson’s investigation and interactive.

answers.content: Gravity, sunlight, animals
answers.explanation: Gravity and sunlight were not discussed as agents of weathering in this lesson.

answers.content: Ice, wind, humans
answers.explanation: Humans were not included; ice was not one of the three key agents in this lesson.

answers.content: Volcanoes, earthquakes, water
answers.explanation: Volcanoes and earthquakes are rapid change agents, not gradual weathering forces highlighted here.

questions.question: How does weathering differ from erosion?

answers.content: Weathering breaks rock apart; erosion transports the broken pieces.
answers.explanation: Weathering is the breakdown, erosion is the movement.

answers.content: Weathering happens quickly; erosion is always slow.
answers.explanation: Both can be slow or fast; the key difference is breaking vs. moving.

answers.content: Erosion only occurs under water; weathering only occurs on land.
answers.explanation: Both processes can occur in many environments.

answers.content: They are exactly the same process.
answers.explanation: They are related but distinct.

questions.question: Write two causal connectives used to explain weathering in the model paragraph about moving water.

answers.content: Accept any two of: so, as a result, due to
answers.explanation: These connectives link cause (agent) and effect (weathering outcome).

questions.question: In one or two sentences, describe how moving water weathers rocks.

answers.content: Flowing water carries sand or other particles that repeatedly strike rocks, wearing their surfaces smoother and breaking them into smaller pieces over time.
answers.explanation: Answer should mention force of moving water, abrasion by carried particles, and gradual breakdown.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple flow chart showing the sequence of events that lead to a rock becoming smaller and smoother under the force of wind over many years.

answers.content: Teacher-assessed drawing: should include steps such as wind picks up sand – sand hits rock – tiny chips break off – rock becomes rounded/smaller.
answers.explanation: Credit is given for correctly ordered, labelled stages showing cause and effect.

questions.question: In the sugar-cube investigation, which variable represented the passage of time in natural weathering?

answers.content: The length of time the jar was shaken.
answers.explanation: Shaking for longer simulates more years of natural collisions.

answers.content: The colour of the sugar cubes.
answers.explanation: Colour was not related to time.

answers.content: The type of paper used.
answers.explanation: Paper was only to improve visibility.

answers.content: The size of the classroom group.
answers.explanation: Group size does not model time.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the speed at which natural weathering usually occurs?

answers.content: Weathering is generally a very slow process that can take thousands of years.
answers.explanation: Natural rock breakdown happens over long periods, unlike the minutes-long classroom model.

answers.content: Weathering happens in seconds, similar to an explosion.
answers.explanation: This confuses weathering with sudden events.

answers.content: Weathering only happens during a heavy storm.
answers.explanation: While storms can aid weathering, the process continues at other times.

answers.content: Weathering stops once a rock becomes smooth.
answers.explanation: Weathering can continue even after a rock is rounded.

questions.question: What is erosion?

answers.content: The breaking of large rocks into smaller pieces on Earth’s surface.
answers.explanation: This describes weathering, not erosion.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand from one location to another.
answers.explanation: Erosion moves weathered material to a new place.

answers.content: The dropping or settling of sediments in a new location.
answers.explanation: This describes deposition.

answers.content: The slow cooling of lava after a volcanic eruption.
answers.explanation: Unrelated to erosion.

questions.question: In the class investigation, which single factor (independent variable) was changed to test its effect on erosion?

answers.content: The amount of water poured into each tray.
answers.explanation: Same amount of water was used in all trays.

answers.content: The slope of the tray.
answers.explanation: Only the number of books/blocks under the tray was changed.

answers.content: The type of sand used.
answers.explanation: Same sand was used for each test.

answers.content: The temperature of the water.
answers.explanation: Temperature was not varied.

questions.question: Which tray is expected to show the greatest amount of erosion?

answers.content: Tray 1 (flat)
answers.explanation: Water flows slowest on a flat surface.

answers.content: Tray 2 (gentle slope)
answers.explanation: Shows some erosion but less than tray 3.

answers.content: Tray 3 (steep slope)
answers.explanation: Steeper slope increases water speed and force, causing more erosion.

answers.content: All trays should show the same amount of erosion.
answers.explanation: Different slopes produce different erosion rates.

questions.question: Explain why water flowing down a steeper slope causes more erosion than water flowing down a gentle slope.

answers.content: Water moves faster on a steeper slope, so it has more force to pick up and carry sand and soil away.
answers.explanation: Speed increases kinetic energy/force, which lifts and transports more sediment.

questions.question: When scientists carry out a fair test, they:

answers.content: Change as many factors as possible at once.
answers.explanation: Changing many variables makes results unreliable.

answers.content: Keep all factors the same except the one they want to test.
answers.explanation: Only the independent variable should change.

answers.content: Never repeat their experiments.
answers.explanation: Repetition improves reliability.

answers.content: Choose the result they expected.
answers.explanation: Scientists report observed results, not preferred ones.

questions.question: The Dreaming story ‘Super Snake’ offers one explanation for the formation of landforms. What alternative explanation is provided in the scientific perspective discussed in class?

answers.content: Landforms are formed by humans using tools.
answers.explanation: Not discussed.

answers.content: Natural forces such as wind and water shape landforms over time.
answers.explanation: Scientific perspective emphasises wind and water erosion.

answers.content: Landforms appear suddenly without cause.
answers.explanation: Science explains them through ongoing processes.

answers.content: Animals dig most landforms.
answers.explanation: Animals can influence land but were not the primary focus here.

questions.question: Name two natural forces that can cause erosion and briefly describe how each one moves sediment.

answers.content: Wind – blows soil and sand through the air; Water – carries sediment as it flows.
answers.explanation: Both forces transport weathered material to new locations.

questions.question: Draw and label the set-up of one of the trays used in the investigation, showing the slope, sand ‘river’, and the direction of water flow.

answers.content: Student provides a labelled diagram with slope height, sand river channel and arrow indicating water flow.
answers.explanation: Diagram demonstrates understanding of experimental design.
